bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 30, 1929

div1.p: Carter updates Russell on progress made on the geographic lists for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 30, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report- Weekly
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
May 30, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I had intended writing to you again e'er this, but have
been hoping each day for news from Baltimore. None so far.

The alphabetic card index list of names of countries: rivers:
towns: islands etc. mentioned in Father's MS has been very fully and
carefully compiled, including pagination, on the individual cards, of
each additional mention of the place in question. This took very little
extra time inwhile going over the MS and may be useful to Dr. Frost for
cross-references or--possibly--later for indexing.

The next step is for Miss Brown and myself to go over these
geographic files carefully together, making duplicate cards (from those
we have for the enlarged map of Middle America and the northern part of
South America) of places sufficiently important to appear on the less
detailed map of this section--i. e. that comprised in part of the map?
of Mercator's projection for the West Coast of Africa and the East
Coast of the Americas facing it. This we had hoped to do before now,
but Miss Brown has had severe cold and I another gastro-intestinal upset,
which combination has prevented our getting together. Miss Brown
telephoned to-day that her cold was better, but as I share Father's sus-
ceptibility to respiratory troubles, I thought we might save time by
putting off our joint work, althought there is nothing that she would
have liked better than spending all of her holiday (Memorial Day) in
working on the book. She has been putting in her nights on these geo-
graphic lists, even with the cold.

The next time I go to the Library of Congress, I shall see
about having a photostat taken from the Book of Chilam Balam
Balam
-2-
of Chumayel (the excerpt containing the first mention of yellow fever
(1648) in the Mayan historic books). This excerpt Dr. Frost “o. k.d”
the last time I was in Baltimore, as one of the illustrations for the
book. It had long been tentatively so considered, but now I can go
ahead with it.
With very best remembrances, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
